identificationModule.briefTitle: A Randomized Trial of Imaging Selection Modalities for Stroke Thrombectomy (NO-SELECT)
identificationModule.officialTitle: Simple Imaging Versus Standard Imaging Selection in Stroke Patients for Endovascular Treatment: the NO-SELECT Cluster-randomized, Crossover Trial

descriptionModule.briefSummary:
Several studies suggest that advanced multi-modal imaging with CTP should be used to screen late time window stroke patients for thrombectomy. However, NCCT is more accessible when comparing with CTP. It is unclear whether the NCCT-based ASPECTS can be used as an imaging criterion to screen patients for thrombectomy.

The newly published MR CLEAN-LATE and TENSION trials used NCCT or CTA, but still relied on ASPECTS scores to evaluate and select patients for endovascular therapy. However, different trials have different time windows. The aim of this trial was to assess the clinical outcomes of stroke patients with anterior large vessel occlusion who selected by simple imaging (NCCT) comparing via standard imaging screening strategy (CTP/MRI). The hypothesis is that simple imaging is non-inferior to standard imaging selection strategy in terms of achieving favorable outcomes.

keywords: Alberta Stroke Program Early CT score

armGroups.label: Simple imaging
armGroups.description: NCCT and CTA will be used to screen patients for endovascular treatment

armGroups.label: Standard imaging
armGroups.description: NCCT-ASPECTS (pc-ASPECTS), CTA, and CTP will be used to screen patients for endovascular treatment

interventions.name: Simplified imaging strategy
interventions.description: NCCT and CTA will be used to screen patients for endovascular treatment

interventions.name: Standard imaging strategy
interventions.description: NCCT-ASPECTS (pc-ASPECTS), CTA, and CTP will be used to screen patients for endovascular treatment

primaryOutcomes.description: defined as modified Rankin scale score of 0 to 3. Modified Rankin scale score (mRS): scores range from 0 to 6, with 0 indicating no disability, 1 no clinically significant disability, 2 slight disability, 3 moderate disability but able to walk unassisted, 4 moderately severe disability, 5 severe disability, and 6 death.

secondaryOutcomes.description: symptomatic intracranial hemorrhage according to Heidelberg criteria
defined as the number of deaths observed divided by the number of subjects observed over the 90-day study period

ipdSharingStatementModule.timeFrame: Related papers published 6 months later, the IPD will be shared
